Key Match Events: Harry Kane opens the scoring for England from close range in the 18th minute.
Morten Hjulmand’s scorching 30-yard drive just after the half-hour secures a draw for Denmark.
Phil Foden hits the post in the second half.
Kyle Walker slips twice in the early running, rolling his ankle on the second occasion but continues after changing his boots.
Conor Gallagher is introduced for Trent Alexander-Arnold on 54 minutes.
Phil Foden almost scores with a rasping low drive from distance that rattles the upright.
Ollie Watkins forces a save from Kasper Schmeichel after a pass from Jude Bellingham.
Marc Guéhi makes a crucial tackle after being dispossessed by Alexander Bah.
Post-Match Reflections: Gareth Southgate accepts blame for England draw and admits ‘level has to be higher’.
England lacked structure and progressive patterns in midfield, with all three of Southgate’s starters – Trent Alexander-Arnold, Declan Rice and Jude Bellingham – enduring difficult games.
Southgate raised eyebrows when he withdrew his front three of Bukayo Saka, Harry Kane and Phil Foden on 70 minutes.
England looked edgy, the pressure weighing heavily.
Denmark good value for the draw, which they secured with Morten Hjulmand’s goal.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The turf cut up noticeably, causing problems for many players.
The chant from the Denmark support – to the tune of Yellow Submarine – was heard outside the stadium before kick-off and reverberated inside during the match.
The closed roof of the Frankfurt Arena created a remorseless din, making it difficult for players to hear shouts from teammates.
